item.title: Arab leaders urge international community to stop applying 'double standards' to Israel
item.description: An Israeli strike on Doha last week has set off a wave of condemnation, with Arab and Islamic leaders gathering in Qatar to arrive at a united response. Israel, meanwhile, is standing firm, deepening its alliance with Washington as the war in Gaza rages on.

item.title: SBS News in Easy English 15th September 2025
item.description: A daily five minute news wrap for English learners and people with disability.

item.title: Adolescence star Owen Cooper becomes youngest male actor to win an Emmy
item.description: The four-part series he starred in recorded 140 million views in its first three months on Netflix, and drew rave reviews.

item.title: 'No Australian spared': National Climate Risk Assessment delivers dire warning
item.description: Coastal hazards driven by climate change could put three million people at risk by 2090 if Australia warms by 3 degrees, according to a major body of new climate research released by the federal government. The National Climate Risk Assessment has been released, as the government prepares the ground to announce its carbon emissions reduction target for 2035.

item.title: 'We take it very seriously': Queenslander charged over Nazi salute at AFL game
item.description: A spectator has received a lifetime AFL ban after being accused of performing a Nazi salute at a major finals clash.

item.title: ANZ cops $240m fine for widespread misconduct
item.description: The Australian share market has begun the week lower, despite optimism ahead of the US Federal Reserve’s expected interest rate cut this week. For more, Stephanie Youssef spoke with Macquarie Private Bank Division Director Martin Lakos. Plus, ANZ has been fined $240 million for what ASIC has called widespread misconduct, including allegations of failing to respond to customer hardship notices and failing to refund fees charged to thousands of dead customers. For more, Asha Abdi spoke with Professor Allan Fels from the University of Melbourne.

item.title: How much money do you really need to be happy? Here's what the research says
item.description: Recent data shows that economic inequality in Australia is increasing.

item.title: Inside the 'hyper-connected' nationalist groups fuelling protests in Australia and the UK
item.description: There is a complex picture behind the recent mobilisation of the far-right across Australia and the UK. But experts say it's happened before.

item.title: Kurtis Marschall takes pole vault bronze for Australia at World Athletics Championships 2025
item.description: Pole vaulter Kurtis Marschall has won Australia's first medal of the Tokyo world championships and Mondo Duplantis has broken his own world record in the event.

item.title: Gout Gout is through to his World Athletics Championships semi-final. Here's how to watch
item.description: The Australian sprinting sensation is making his senior international debut in Tokyo. Here's what you need to know.

item.title: Liberal senator warns of 'mass exodus' from Coalition frontbench over net zero
item.description: The Liberal party is once again at loggerheads over the party's stance on net zero, with another frontbencher warning against adopting a policy "at any cost".

item.title: 'Israel is fighting a war of slavery': Strong criticism from emergency summit in Qatar
item.description: Arab and Islamic leaders have met in Doha following Israel’s strike that killed Hamas officials and a Qatari security officer. Qatar’s Emir accused Israel of seeking dominance, while Iran, Turkey and Egypt called for sanctions, isolation and regional defence coordination.

item.title: What social media platforms will — and won't — have to do under Australia's under-16s ban
item.description: Australia's eSafety commissioner has unveiled guidelines for social media companies to comply with age restriction laws that will come into effect on 10 December. Here's what we know.

item.title: SBS News in Easy English 16 September 2025
item.description: A daily five minute news wrap for English learners and people with disability.

item.title: Cash-for-votes, deepfakes and propaganda: Russia's latest bid for influence
item.description: As Russia's neighbour prepares to head to the polls, a pro-Russian alliance appears to be on the rise thanks, in part, to a disinformation and propaganda campaign some believe is backed by the Kremlin.

item.title: Australian dollar hits a 10 month high against the US
item.description: SBS Finance Editor Ricardo Gonçalves takes a look at the driving forces in the currency markets with Chris Weston from Pepperstone and previews the US Federal Reserve's Thursday morning interest rate decision.

item.title: Israel has committed genocide against Palestinians in Gaza, UN inquiry finds
item.description: The UN commission of inquiry concluded that Israeli authorities and forces had, since October 2023, committed "four of the five genocidal acts" listed in the 1948 Genocide Convention.

item.title: Deep rifts widen further within Coalition under climate change pressure
item.description: Liberal senator Jonathan Duniam has warned the Coalition will face a "mass exodus" from its frontbench if it adopts a net zero policy without caveats, handing Opposition leader Sussan Ley a fresh test over the party's stance on climate action. The warning comes a day after Liberal MP Andrew Hastie threatened to quit the party if it pursued a policy of net zero emissions by 2050.

item.title: 'As data-minimising as possible': under-16 social media ban guidelines published
item.description: Australia's eSafety commissioner has published regulatory guidelines for social media platforms, giving effect to the government's under-16 social media ban. While the ban won't be in place until December 10th, the eSafety commissioner says they want it to be as minimally invasive as possible. Under the guidance, social media platforms will not have to verify the age of every user on their platforms.

item.title: Cocaine, cartels, and questions: Concerns over Trump's drug boat 'hunt'
item.description: The US has carried out deadly strikes on Venezuelan boats it alleges carried 'narcoterrorists'. But are these killings lawful? And why is the US turning its focus to the South American nation?

item.title: Modified and dangerous: The popular 'illegal motorbikes' on Australia's roads
item.description: Modified e-bikes that can run well over their legal speed limit are causing serious injuries and even deaths — is it time for Australia to crack down?

item.title: When Andrea’s husband died, their blended family was 'instantaneously decimated'
item.description: Maintaining contact with step or blended family after a separation can be difficult and give rise to mixed emotions — especially when there are no legal responsibilities between stepparents and stepchildren.

item.title: Chalmers reacts to Trump's rebuke as ABC journalist says president was 'feisty'
item.description: The ABC's Americas editor John Lyons joked he would have to "brace himself" after US President Donald Trump said he was going to tell Prime Minister Anthony Albanese about him.

item.title: Australia-PNG defence pact on hold, but PM insists it'll still be inked
item.description: Prime Minister Anthony Albanese was expected to sign the landmark defence treaty while visiting Papua New Guinea.

item.title: SBS News in Easy English 17 September 2025
item.description: A daily five minute news wrap for English learners and people with disability.

item.title: Four arrested after Epstein, Trump images projected on castle ahead of president's visit
item.description: Four adults were arrested on suspicion of malicious communications after protesters unfurled a massive banner featuring a photograph of Trump and Epstein near Windsor Castle, and later projected several images of the pair onto one of its towers.

item.title: Charlie Kirk's alleged killer has been charged. Trump's base has its sights on a different target
item.description: Fears are growing of a looming crackdown on Donald Trump's perceived political opponents after the US president and members of his administration warned the "radical left" would face consequences for the assassination of right-wing commentator Charlie Kirk.

item.title: No deal: Albanese leaves empty-handed after PNG delays defence pact
item.description: The Prime Minister is leaving Papua New Guinea empty-handed after a landmark security agreement wasn't signed in the final hours. The delayed deal comes less than two weeks after a similar defence with Vanuatu was delayed over concerns it will affect their other relationships.

item.title: The bank of mum and dad helping first home buyers, & investors look to US Federal Reserve
item.description: Parents and grandparents are increasingly offering financial assistance to family members with 20 per cent saying they provided help in the last quarter, so SBS Finance Editor Ricardo Gonçalves speaks with UBS Economist Stephen Wu to find out to what extent they're helping. Plus Kyle Rodda from capital.com looks through the day's sharemarket action and previews the Federal Reserve's interest rate decision.

item.title: Australia's newest citizens welcomed in ceremonies on Australian Citizenship Day
item.description: Thousands are celebrating becoming new Australians, as local councils hosted ceremonies around the country for Australian Citizenship Day. SBS spoke to some of the new citizens.

item.title: Gout Gout soars into semifinal 'against the big dogs' at World Athletics Championships
item.description: Sprint sensation Gout Gout has lived up to the hype by qualifying for the 200m semi-finals at the world championships.

item.title: I grew up in several blended families. Olivia was the only stable maternal figure in my life
item.description: Actor and singer Tottie Goldsmith didn’t have much contact with her mother growing up and was raised in blended families as her dad remarried several times. She says that she craved emotional stability and connection during this time and so found a consistent maternal figure in her late aunt, Olivia Newton-John.

item.title: The key question for Australia after UN report's Gaza genocide finding
item.description: The UN Independent International Commission of Inquiry report found Israel is committing genocide in Gaza — an accusation it denies. Experts say the recommendations provide a blueprint for the Australian government to take stronger action, but will it?

item.title: Pomp, protests and an 'eternal' bond on day one of Donald Trump's UK state visit
item.description: The visit, marked by record security, protests and awkward questions over Jeffrey Epstein, is being used by UK Prime Minister Keir Starmer to push trade talks and secure major US tech investments.

item.title: The transnational links between extremist groups fuelling protests in Australia and the UK
item.description: Experts say there are a number of driving forces behind recent mass demonstrations in Australia and the UK, and says they are "not particularly exceptional". They also say media organisations need to treat this issue with caution when reporting.

item.title: Albanese unveils 2035 emissions reduction target — and billions in new funding
item.description: The federal government has unveiled a target to cut emissions by 62 to 70 per cent.

item.title: Calls for change to Low Income Super Tax Offset rule
Jimmy Kimmel Live taken off air indefinitely after host's Charlie Kirk comments
item.description: Kimmel suggested during his show this week that Donald Trump's base had used the death of right-wing commentator Kirk for political gain.

item.title: Palestinians fleeing Gaza City as Israel opens additional exit passage
item.description: Hundreds of thousands of Gazans are fleeing south as Israel’s bombardment of the enclave intensifies, with families forced to carry children and the elderly along designated so-called safe routes.Meanwhile, Israel’s far-right finance minister has controversially described Gaza as a potential real estate bonanza once demolished.

item.title: SBS News in Easy English 18 September 2025
item.description: A daily five minute news wrap for English learners and people with disability.

item.title: 'Not likely to please anyone': Labor's 'ambitious' new emissions target faces criticism
item.description: The updated target has been criticised as both insufficient and overly ambitious.

item.title: Too high or too low? Australia's 2035 climate target pleases no one
item.description: As one of the world's biggest greenhouse gas emitters per capita, Australia has announced its new 2035 emissions reduction target. The federal government has committed to a target to cut emissions by 62 to 70 per cent by 2035, based on 2005 levels. Some say the target is too high, others say it's too low. Labor says it's both ambitious and achievable.

item.title: Full-time jobs tumble, US cuts rates & future of chocolate prices
item.description: SBS Finance Editor Ricardo Gonçalves speaks with Blair Chapman from Seek about the latest jobs data which showed a near 41,000 fall in full-time jobs; Lochlan Halloway from Morningstar takes a look at the day's sharemarket action including the reaction to the US Federal Reserve's first interst rate cut this year; and Stephanie Youssef discusses the future of chocolate prices with Paul Joules from Rabobank.

item.title: The $500 million problem caused by an 'out-of-date' super rule
item.description: One part of Australia's superannuation system has been "frozen for years" — and its a problem that could be leaving some shortchanged, according to a new report.

item.title: Trump's royal treatment, UN declares 'genocide' in Gaza & Albania's AI minister
item.description: Donald Trump gets some face time with the King & Queen on a state visit to the UK. A UN commission of inquiry finds Israel’s war in Gaza amounts to genocide as Israel’s ground operation in Gaza City gets underway. MAGA vows war on the left in response to Charlie Kirk's killing and Bolsonaro is sentenced to 27 years in jail. Plus, Albania unveils an all AI minister.

item.title: Foreign policy, free speech and Epstein: Takeaways from Trump and Starmer's press conference
item.description: The US and UK leaders hailed the renewal of the countries' "special relationship" as Trump's state visit drew to a close.

item.title: Gout Gout is out of the World Athletics Championships — but time is on his side
item.description: The 17-year-old placed fourth in the second semi-final on Thursday night with a time of 20.36 seconds.

item.title: Ned's grandson died in police custody. Three months on, the cause still isn't confirmed.
item.description: The police-led investigation into Kumanjayi White's death in custody is still ongoing, amid growing frustration and anger from the Yuendumu community.

item.title: The Aussie dollar is having a moment. Here's what it means for you
item.description: The Australian dollar is trading at around a 10-month high against the US dollar and has been broadly performing "very well". But it's not the whole story, experts say.

item.title: Sydney's army of Olympic volunteers mark 25 years
item.description: This week marks 25 years since the opening of the Sydney Olympics. From welcoming athletes to washing t-shirts, an army of than 46,000 volunteers helped maintain the smooth running of the games - including pioneer volunteers who volunteered in the years leading up to the games.

item.title: SBS News in Easy English 19 September 2025
item.description: A daily five minute news wrap for English learners and people with disability.

item.title: What we know about Charlie Kirk's memorial service
item.description: Charlie Kirk, a right-wing political commentator, was assassinated while speaking at a university campus in the US state of Utah last week.

item.title: Why we're retiring five years later — and the 'big problem' for future generations
item.description: A "significant shift" has pushed back the age Australians are retiring, according to an author of a new report.

item.title: 'Right plan for Australia': Government ministers defend 2035 climate target
item.description: Climate advocates say the federal government's 2035 emissions reduction target falls "dangerously short", while the Coalition has said its plan is "grounded in fantasy land". Government ministers are now working to justify the target to the public and the community, as the Coalition is under pressure to outline their climate policy.

item.title: Age pension to rise & is AI in bubble territory?
item.description: Stephanie Youssef speaks with Omkar Joshi from Opal Capital Management for the day's sharemarket news, including whether AI is in bubble territory, while SBS Finance Editor Ricardo Gonçalves goes through the upcoming age pension changes with Joshua Parisotto from HESTA.

item.title: Israelis shot at Allenby Crossing into Jordan
item.description: The Israeli military has confirmed four of its personnel were killed in Rafah as well as two Israeli citizens, in a shooting described as a terrorist attack at Allenby Crossing. The crisis has deepened divisions around the world and at the United Nations, where a US veto blocked a resolution calling for a ceasefire and unrestricted aid.

item.title: Three people dead after Optus network upgrade sparked triple-zero call failure
item.description: Two of the deceased were from South Australia and one from Western Australia, Optus CEO Stephen Rue said.

item.title: 'Really angry': Isabel is one of hundreds considering class action against this IVF provider
item.description: Hundreds of Australians have shown interest in a class action lawsuit, which could be the first test of new reforms to Australia's Privacy Act.

item.title: Free speech fears continue to roil US as Trump says unfair media coverage is 'illegal'
item.description: What began as a late-night joke has spiralled into a test of free speech in Trump’s America.

item.title: Healing land and spirit through Noongar knowledge and regenerative land management
item.description: In Western Australia's Wheatbelt, a region long shaped by industrial farming practices, a new model of regenerative agriculture is taking root. At Yaraguia farm, Ballardong Noongar man Oral McGuire is healing Country, reconnecting First Nations knowledge of caring for Country with modern land management to restore ecosystems and produce food that benefits both the land and the community.

item.title: 'Incredibly tragic event': Fourth death linked to 10-hour Optus triple-zero outage
item.description: South Australian Premier Peter Malinauskas blasted the telco's slow and "bewildering" response, vowing it would be held to account for the outage that affected approximately 600 triple-zero calls.

item.title: 'Incredibly tragic event': Fourth death linked to 10-hour Optus triple-zero outage
item.description: South Australian Premier Peter Malinauskas blasted the telco's slow and "bewildering" response, vowing it would be held to account for the outage that affected approximately 600 triple-zero calls.

item.title: I feel like privacy is dead: IVF data breach triggers interest in class action lawsuit
item.description: After years of trying to conceive, Isabel Lewis thought the hard part was over — until cybercriminals targeted her fertility clinic. The data breach at Genea Fertility included patient's medical histories, diagnoses and treatments, medications and prescriptions, as well as pathology and diagnostic test results. Now, hundreds of Australians have shown interest in a class action lawsuit over the breach, which could be the first test of new reforms to Australia's Privacy Act.

item.title: The 80th General Assembly of the UN is meeting in New York. How does it work - and why?
item.description: World leaders will gather in New York next week for the annual General Assembly. Secretary-General Antonio Guterres has highlighted peace, climate, responsible innovation, gender equality, development financing and UN reform as central themes of the week. But the high-level week of the General Assembly also marks the 80th anniversary of the founding of the United Nations. We take a look at just what the UNGA is and what its powers are.

item.title: Jess Hull breaks Australian record and qualifies for 800m final at World Athletics Championships
item.description: The 28-year-old recorded a time of 1:57.15 and placed third in her semi-final heat in Tokyo on Friday night.

item.title: Why some Australian parents are giving their kids as much as $200k
item.description: Parents and grandparents are increasingly offering financial assistance to family members with 20 per cent saying they provided help in the last quarter.

item.title: 'Unprecedentedly brazen': Estonia invokes Nato treaty after Russian jets violate airspace
item.description: Russia's defence ministry denied its jets violated Estonian airspace, saying they flew over neutral waters.

item.title: The 'quite simple' way this group of Australians could save lives
item.description: Australians receiving treatment for "urgent" and "critical" diseases are having to wait for people overseas to make life-saving donations.

item.title: 'Not exactly glamorous': The 'disheartening' reality of dating in rural Australia
item.description: Rural Australians say dating in the country is a whole lot harder than in the city, with geographic isolation the least of their worries. Finding someone with the same values and lifestyle priorities is often the hardest challenge, which is why singles events in the sticks are having such a big impact.

item.title: The UN has reached a historic milestone. The world will be watching what it does next
item.description: This week's United Nations meeting will be a landmark occasion for multiple reasons.

item.title: Opinions divided on how to save our precious mountain ash forests
item.description: New research has found Australia's heat-stressed forests are rapidly thinning, and could even be producing carbon emissions. It comes as the government prepares to release its 2035 emissions targets and a climate risk report later this month. But local researchers, politicians and Traditional Owner land groups remain divided on how to protect the forest.

item.title: John Santi lays his brother's remains to rest after finding out museum displayed specimens without consent
item.description: A coronial investigation launched in Tasmania in 2016 has found the University of Tasmania removed and kept human remains without consent or approval. The investigation raises broader questions about collections of human remains in other universities and museums in Australia, and what obligation these institutions have to identify their origin.

item.title: White House issues clarification after Trump hits H-1B visas with $150,000 fee
item.description: The announcement sparked concerns among employees across swaths of corporate America.

item.title: Here's the tea: Global shortage means steep prices for matcha lovers
item.description: Global matcha prices are surging due to poor weather in Japan, rising global demand, labour shortages, and steep US tariffs on imports from Japan and China. Now, the world’s love affair with matcha may be tested - at the checkout counter.

item.title: At least 60 Palestinians killed as Israel presses on with Gaza City assault
item.description: The Israeli military estimates it has demolished up to 20 Gaza City tower blocks over the past two weeks.

item.title: Republicans warn Australia of 'punitive measures' recognising Palestinian statehood
item.description: Anthony Albanese will recognise Palestinian statehood along with other world leaders at the UN General Assembly this week.

item.title: A cyber attack has hit some of Europe's busiest airports. Here's what you need to know
item.description: The cyber attack on check-in systems caused cancellations and long delays for thousands of passengers.

item.title: 'Disgraceful': Optus launches investigation, reveals two more emergency call failures
item.description: Optus says alongside an investigation, it will launch a new compulsory escalation process following any customer reports of 000 failures.

item.title: 'Wait for it': Netanyahu warns Australia, other nations for recognising Palestinian state
item.description: Australia's recognition does not require ratification in the parliament or any United Nations vote to come into effect — it is now official government policy.

item.title: 'Remarkable': How Gaza protests unfolded in Australia and around the world
item.description: Australia is considered a "low protest country" but it has held some of the biggest pro-Palestinian protests in the world. Explore how Gaza protests have unfolded in our interactive map.

item.title: Some Australians are not confident about their retirement. Here's how much you need a year
item.description: Australians looking for work in their 40s and women, especially those divorced or single with children, are not feeling confident about retirement.

item.title: The penalties Optus could face after its 'second significant and egregious failure'
item.description: The Australian Communications and Media Authority has announced its investigation into the Optus triple-zero outage, with the communications minister warning there will be consequences for the sector.

item.title: More Israeli strikes hit Lebanon, Gaza
item.description: An Israeli drone strike on the Lebanese town of Bint Jbeil has killed five people, including three children, despite a US-brokered ceasefire with Hezbollah. The tragedy comes as Gaza endures another wave of bombardments, with dozens killed in the past day alone.

item.title: SBS News in Easy English 22 September 2025
item.description: A daily five minute news wrap for English learners and people with disability.

item.title: Prosecutors to consider charges as police end investigation into Kumanjayi White's death
item.description: A mandatory coronial investigation into the death in custody of Kumanjayi White remains ongoing.

item.title: Simone was a loyal Optus customer. Then her husband needed an ambulance
item.description: Hundreds of calls to triple-zero failed to connect during an Optus network outage linked to three deaths.

item.title: Australia recognises Palestinian state at the UN
item.description: Australia has joined Canada, Portugal and the United Kingdom in formally recognising a Palestinian state at the UN. The declaration was made by Prime Minister Anthony Albanese and Foreign Minister Penny Wong outside the United Nations headquarters in New York City, with the government saying it comes as part of a push for a two-state solution to the Israeli-Palestinian conflict. Israel's Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu has issued a warning to the countries, while saying he aims to ensure there will never be a Palestinian state.

item.title: Spring brings warmer weather, flower shows... and food safety concerns
item.description: As spring has arrived in Australia, a leading food safety advocate group is calling Australians to also conduct a spring clean for their fridges, freezers and pantries. The call comes as a recent survey finds over half of Australians see food-borne illness as their main food safety concerns, but less than half consumers consistently perform food safety behaviours when preparing food at home. And with a hot summer approaching, advocates and health experts say Australians need to be more careful about food poisoning this year

item.title: Australia urged to stand firm on COP31 hosting
Are more interest rate cuts on the cards?
'Optus will be held to account': Penalties on the telco loom as AMCA investigates
item.description: The Federal Communications Minister says Optus can expect to suffer significant consequences following last week's triple-0 outage, that's been linked to multiple deaths. The Australian Communications and Media Authority [[ACMA]] has launched an investigation into the failure, with authorities looking to obtain significant information from the telco to understand what happened.

item.title: Albanese in New York: Will the PM finally meet Trump — and what happens if he doesn't?
item.description: The prime minister has wasted no time since arriving in the Big Apple. What lies ahead?

item.title: 'Russian blood oil': Australia faces calls to ban oil products refined from Russian crude
item.description: Australia has joined a coalition of nations in lowering the price cap on Russian oil and imposing new sanctions on Russia's 'shadow fleet'. But experts warn the move may be little more than a distraction from deeper issues.

item.title: Why Brooke chose Facebook over an IVF clinic to find a sperm donor
item.description: As demand for sperm donors increases, some are avoiding fertility clinics in favour of less formal networks. Meanwhile, for donors, there is a range of ethical considerations and potential unintended consequences to consider.

item.title: Why many Australians don't feel financially confident & ASX rises as market waits for US inflation
item.description: SBS Finance Editor Ricardo Gonçalves speaks with Luke McMillan from Ophir Asset Management about the day's sharemarket action while Stephanie Youssef looks through the latest AMP research with Ben Hillier which reveals half of Australians don't feel financially confident as they approach retirement.

item.title: 'A uniquely delicate crime': Dangers of stealthing poorly understood by Australians
item.description: Stealthing, the removal of a condom during sex without a partner's knowledge or consent, has in recent years become a criminal offence in almost all parts of Australia. But experts say there is still a lack of awareness about what stealthing is and the dangers it poses.

item.title: UK charities end links with Prince Andrew's ex-wife over Epstein email
item.description: In a 2011 email to convicted US sex offender Jeffrey Epstein, the ex-wife of disgraced Prince Andrew, Sarah Ferguson, said she considered him a "supreme friend" and apologised for publicly disowning him.

item.title: Qantas warns of flight disruptions as Typhoon Ragasa approaches Hong Kong
item.description: Thousands of people have been evacuated in the northern Philippines as one of the strongest typhoons this year threatens to cause flooding and landslides.

item.title: Trump is pushing an unproven link between paracetamol and autism. What does the science say?
item.description: Identifying the root of autism has long been a pet cause of Trump's controversial health chief, Robert F Kennedy Jr. But new claims have been rejected by medical experts.

item.title: France joins Australia and others in recognising a Palestinian state at the UN General Assembly
item.description: France has formally recognised the state of Palestine in what President Emmanuel Macron hailed as a historic step towards Middle East peace. The decision, welcomed by Palestinian leaders and backed by several allies, set the tone for the United Nations' 80th anniversary session, even as Israel and the United States condemned it and boycotted proceedings.

item.title: SBS News in Easy English 23 September 2025
item.description: A daily five minute news wrap for English learners and people with disability.

item.title: Why the ICC has charged ex-Philippine president Rodrigo Duterte with crimes against humanity
item.description: The 80-year-old is accused of being criminally responsible for several murders that took place during his so-called 'war on drugs'.

item.title: The states and territories where renters have it the best — and worst
item.description: Two years after a national pledge to deliver a 'Better Deal for Renters', a new report finds progress remains uneven — with rights still dictated by postcode.

item.title: Sydney's 'Night Stalker' rapist admits to committing multiple sexual assaults in 1990s
item.description: Decades after multiple women reported being assaulted in Sydney's Moore Park and inner-west areas in the early 1990s, the 61-year-old admitted to more than a dozen offences.

item.title: Nvidia's huge OpenAI deal, and Myer's profit tumbles
item.description: SBS Finance Editor Ricardo Gonçalves speaks with Michael McCarthy from MooMoo Australia about the day's market action including Myer's disappointing profit result, and Nvidia's huge OpenAI deal.

item.title: Are your blueberries safe? Why a pesticide scare has some concerned
item.description: Pesticide suspended after tests on store-bought berries found high levels of harmful chemicals.

item.title: Third time's a charm? Albanese and Trump meeting confirmed for next month
item.description: Prime Minister Anthony Albanese has finally locked in a formal face-to-face meeting with Donald Trump, after a number of false starts.

item.title: Third time's a charm? Albanese and Trump meeting confirmed for next month
item.description: Prime Minister Anthony Albanese has finally locked in a formal face-to-face meeting with Donald Trump, after a number of false starts.

item.title: Australian doctors describe 'slaughterhouse' in Gaza hospital as medicine runs out
item.description: Two Australian doctors volunteering in one of Gaza's last functioning hospitals say nothing prepared them for what they have witnessed in the past two weeks.

item.title: These girls are only able to study in secret. For many, their 'last hope' is being taken away
item.description: With a new internet ban in the north of Afghanistan in force, members of the diaspora in Australia worry their families will be even more isolated.

item.title: Meeting set between Albanese and Trump | Morning News Bulletin 24 September 2025
item.description: A meeting is finally set between Prime Minister Anthony Albanese and US President, four dead as Israeli tanks advance in Gaza, a new national football competition launched in Sydney.

item.title: Trump says Ukraine in a position to 'fight and win' back all territory lost to Russia
item.description: Donald Trump criticised Russia, saying it had been fighting "aimlessly" in a war that a "real military power" would have won in less than a week.

item.title: Countries 'going to hell' and other key takeaways from Donald Trump's UN speech
item.description: Trump warned that migration is sending Western nations "to hell" and dismissed climate change as a "con job".

item.title: ABC ordered to pay Antoinette Lattouf $150,000 over unlawful sacking
item.description: Lattouf was dismissed three days into a five-day ABC Radio hosting stint in December 2023.

item.title: Super Typhoon Ragasa: Cyclone bears down on southern China after 17 killed in Taiwan
item.description: Millions of people in southern China are in Typhoon Ragasa's sights after the most powerful cyclone of 2025 battered Hong Kong and killed 17 people in Taiwan.

item.title: Super Typhoon Ragasa: Cyclone bears down on southern China after 17 killed in Taiwan
item.description: Millions of people in southern China are in Typhoon Ragasa's sights after the most powerful cyclone of 2025 battered Hong Kong and killed 17 people in Taiwan.

item.title: Super Typhoon Ragasa: Cyclone bears down on southern China after 17 killed in Taiwan
item.description: Millions of people in southern China are in Typhoon Ragasa's sights after the most powerful cyclone of 2025 battered Hong Kong and killed 17 people in Taiwan.

item.title: Super Typhoon Ragasa: Cyclone bears down on southern China after 17 killed in Taiwan
item.description: Millions of people in southern China are in Typhoon Ragasa's sights after the most powerful cyclone of 2025 battered Hong Kong and killed 17 people in Taiwan.

item.title: Australian doctors threatened in Gaza | Midday News Bulletin 24 September 2025
item.description: In this bulletin... Australian doctors threatened and forced to flee as they provide care in Gaza, Super Typhoon Ragasa lashing Hong Kong, England announces its five-test Series team as it looks to regain the Ashes from Australia.

item.title: SBS News in Easy English 24 September 2025
item.description: A daily five minute news wrap for English learners and people with disability.

item.title: 150-plus countries now recognise Palestine - what does it mean and could it impact the war?
item.description: Australia has joined 150-plus countries who now officially recognise a Palestinian state. But after nearly two years of war in Gaza, and a death toll in excess of 65,000, what would a state of Palestine even look like? Is this recognition purely symbolic, or does it have real-world implications? And could it help bring an end to the conflict?

item.title: Donald Trump walks his own path on autism research. Health experts say claims don't stack up
item.description: US President Donald Trump has announced his administration will direct doctors not to recommend paracetamol for pregnant women, claiming it may be linked to autism in children. Australian medical experts have responded, re-confirming that paracetamol is safe for use in pregnancy.

item.title: NT hit-and-run case spotlights deep disparities in criminal justice system, advocates say
item.description: The Northern Territory has been engulfed by significant backlash regarding the sentencing of a driver who fatally struck an Aboriginal man in a hit and run and his familial connection to the Territory's Attorney General. First Nations communities and legal experts argue the sentence given to Jake Danby, a 12-month community corrections order, is inconsistent with the 'tough on crime' approach of the Country Liberal Party government.

item.title: Aboriginal people report less respectful hospital care. Here's what can make a difference
item.description: More than a quarter of Aboriginal patients said there had been a time in the past year they needed to go to hospital but didn't, a report has found.

item.title: 'Should've done more': Commissioner's apology at Tian Jarrah Denniss inquest
item.description: The Corrective Services NSW commissioner has delivered an apology to the family of Indigenous man Tian Jarrah Denniss, who died in custody in 2023.

item.title: Three-year inflation high could mean 'wafer-thin' chance of interest rate cut pre November
item.description: Freshly released inflation data will prompt the Reserve Bank to keep the cash rate on hold in September, but a cut in November is still "very much on the cards", experts say.

item.title: Optus fined $100 million for unconscionable sales practices | Evening News Bulletin 24 September 2025
item.description: Optus to pay $100 million fine for sales practices targeting vulnerable Australians; Inflation hits a 12-month high; and in sport, the Wallabies suffer injury blow ahead of Bledisloe opener.

item.title: President Trump's extraordinary address at the UN General Assembly
item.description: Donald Trump has stunned the United Nations, using his speech at the General Assembly to suggest other countries are “going to hell” because of migration and denying science by calling climate change a ‘con’. In an extraordinary address, he slammed the UN for not doing enough to end wars. The US President also said he’d support NATO countries shooting down a Russian aircraft that breaches their airspace, and declared Kyiv can win back ‘all of Ukraine’.

item.title: Higher inflation threatens rate cuts & is the US market overvalued?
item.description: SBS Finance Editor Ricardo Gonçalves speaks with Paul Bloxham from HSBC about today's stronger than expected inflation figures and what it means for interest rates, plus the day on the sharemarket with Francesco De Stradis from Ord Minnett.

item.title: Optus to pay $100m fine for sales practices targeting vulnerable Australians
item.description: Amid Optus' triple-zero outage crisis, the Federal Court has added to the company's woes after approving a $100 million penalty for "appalling and predatory" conduct in the telco's sales practices.

item.title: This Christian community embraces traditional living. But ex-members allege it has dark secrets
item.description: When Dateline journalist Rhiona-Jade Armont travelled to the US for a story about tradwives, she’d never heard of Homestead Heritage. She soon learned the Christian group had a dark history of abuse — and former members allege there’s more. But current members and leaders say it’s a sovereign sanctuary from the outside world.

item.title: 'Anti-ICE' message found on unused bullet after fatal attack on Dallas immigration office
item.description: US Homeland Security secretary Kristi Noem and vice president JD Vance condemned rhetoric directed at Immigration and Customs Enforcement (ICE) since Donald Trump's return to office.

item.title: Anthony Albanese meets Donald Trump in New York | Morning News Bulletin 25 September 2025
item.description: Albanese and Trump meet socially as Penny Wong clarifies Australia's concerns to her Iranian counterpart; Europe backs Australia's impending ban on underage social media accounts; and in sport, two players at the centre of an A-League betting scandal are sentenced.

item.title: Stop Russia's war or face dangerous arms race, Zelenskyy tells UN
item.description: Volodymyr Zelenskyy also accused Vladimir Putin of seeking to expand his war beyond Ukraine.

item.title: Greta Thunberg calls alleged drone attacks on aid flotilla a 'scare tactic' as UN demands probe
item.description: The United Nations has called for an independent investigation into alleged drone attacks on the Global Sumud Flotilla, an international convoy carrying humanitarian aid to Gaza.

item.title: Greta Thunberg calls alleged drone attacks on aid flotilla a 'scare tactic' as UN demands probe
item.description: The United Nations has called for an independent investigation into alleged drone attacks on the Global Sumud Flotilla, an international convoy carrying humanitarian aid to Gaza.

item.title: 'Warm chat' and a selfie: Albanese finally comes face-to-face with Trump
item.description: Anthony Albanese has met Donald Trump at the president's welcome reception for world leaders in New York after the pair locked in a formal sit-down for October.

item.title: Albanese pushes for Security Council seat and calls out Iran in first major UN speech
item.description: The UN risks "being trusted with nothing" unless it works together to tackle climate change and end wars in Gaza and Ukraine, Prime Minister Anthony Albanese has said during his first UN General Assembly address.

item.title: When will humans return to the moon? NASA's new mission is offering clues
item.description: The last time humans landed on the moon was in December 1972.

item.title: When will humans return to the moon? NASA's new mission is offering clues
item.description: The last time humans landed on the moon was in December 1972.

item.title: PM urges greater cooperation at UN | Midday News Bulletin 25 September 2025
item.description: In this bulletin, the Prime Minister to meet with Turkey as both countries bid to host a major climate conference, police voice concern over a surge in Victorian crime rate in recent years. And in football, FIFA considers expanding to 64 countries to mark 100 years of the World Cup.

item.title: Greenlandic girls as young as 12 were forcibly fitted with IUDs. Denmark just apologised
item.description: By the end of 1970, roughly every second Greenland-born woman of childbearing age had been fitted with an IUD.

item.title: Greenlandic girls as young as 12 were forcibly fitted with IUDs. Denmark just apologised
item.description: By the end of 1970, roughly every second Greenland-born woman of childbearing age had been fitted with an IUD.

item.title: Liberal Gisele Kapterian abandons court challenge and concedes defeat in Bradfield
item.description: After 145 days, Liberal Gisele Kapterian has conceded defeat in the Sydney seat of Bradfield to her rival, independent MP Nicolette Boele.

item.title: Anthony Albanese makes the case for Australia at the UN
item.description: Prime Minister Anthony Albanese has delivered his first leader's speech to the United Nations General Assembly, promoting Australia as a significant middle power. He's used the speech to push for more global co-operation on tackling the climate crisis, and peacekeeping efforts. And he's also pushing for Australia to co-host the next COP climate summit in 2026, and hold a seat on the UN Security Council.

item.title: SBS News in Easy English 25 September 2025
item.description: A daily five minute news wrap for English learners and people with disability.

item.title: 'Thanks for waking me up': Untold story behind Cathy Freeman's Olympic glory
item.description: On the 25th anniversary of Cathy Freeman's 400m gold win at the Sydney Olympics, John-Paul Janke looks back at the time she stayed at his home in Canberra.

item.title: It's 'third time lucky' for an Alzheimer's drug. But many Australians like Peter will miss out
item.description: Australia's medicines watchdog has approved Alzheimer's drug lecanemab, which has been shown to "significantly" extend quality of life. But it comes at a great cost.

item.title: Australia pushes for seat on UN Security Council | Evening News Bulletin 25 September 2025
item.description: In this bulletin, the Prime Minister bids for Australia to have a seat on the UN Security Council, a grieving mother urges global leaders to follow Australia's child social media ban. And in rugby league, Melbourne Storm coach Craig Bellamy says returning halfback Jahrome Hughes' teammates will protect him from harm.

item.title: INTERVIEW: Penny Wong on the upcoming Albanese-Trump meeting and Australia's bid to host COP31
item.description: Foreign Minister Penny Wong says the upcoming meeting between Anthony Albanese and Donald Trump will seek to advance areas of co-operation but also underline issues of sovereignty.

item.title: Special Episode: Palestine recognition, Trump unfiltered & paracetamol panic
item.description: Ten Western nations (including Australia, the UK, and France) formally recognise a Palestinian state at the UN General Assembly. Our correspondents bring you the latest from New York, as they break down the statehood debate, MAGA’s escalating war on the left, and Trump’s unsubstantiated claims linking paracetamol and autism.

item.title: New research shows more Australians being harmed by gambling
item.description: An increasing number of Australians are being harmed by gambling according to new research. The study highlights the link between problem gambling and domestic violence, suicide, and financial hardship, with more than 3-million Australians said to be impacted.

item.title: Industries at risk of technology and AI & big dividend day
item.description: SBS Finance Editor Ricardo Gonçalves delves into Barrenjoey's report on the industries most exposed to technological change and AI with Johnathan McMenamin; plus the day on the sharemarket with Mark Gardner from MPC Markets.

item.title: Key questions behind this controversial United Nations address
item.description: He once led a designated terrorist group. Now, Syria's Ahmed al-Sharaa leads the country and has addressed the United Nations. But was his appearance there really another step in a "dramatic" political transformation?

item.title: 'Hybrid attack': Drones over Danish airports intended to spread fear, authorities say
item.description: The incidents are just the latest in a series of drone incursions — including two days ago in Denmark — in the past few weeks that have exposed the vulnerability of European airspace.

item.title: Former French President Nicolas Sarkozy jailed for five years over Libyan criminal conspiracy case
item.description: Sarkozy, who has always denied the charges, was accused of making a deal with former Libyan leader Muammar Gaddafi to obtain campaign financing.

item.title: Australia's battle to take out a rival bid and host its 'biggest diplomatic summit ever'
item.description: The summit would likely provide an economic boost for the hopeful host city, Adelaide, after a record 80,000 people attended last year's event in Dubai.

item.title: From Silicon Valley to Sydney: How Trump's H-1B visa move could make ripples in Australia
item.description: As Donald Trump's H-1B visa order seeks to restrict the United States' intake of skilled migrants, could it provide an opportunity for Australia?

item.title: Perth grandmother loses drug-smuggling appeal in Japan | Morning News Bulletin 26 September 2025
item.description: An Australian woman loses her drug smuggling appeal in Japan; The President of the State of Palestine addresses the UN General Assembly; And in sport, Lions co-captain Lachie Neale named in the side for the AFL grand final.

item.title: Palestinian leader condemns Israel's assault on Gaza, rejects Hamas during UN address
item.description: Palestinian Authority President Mahmoud Abbas addressed the UN General Assembly via video, accusing Israel of war crimes and declaring that Hamas will have no future role in governing Gaza.

item.title: 'Unauthorised' edit of Australian film Together removes same-sex couple for audiences in China
item.description: The film Together has reportedly been altered using artificial intelligence by a Chinese film distributor.

item.title: Donald Trump says any Israeli annexation of the West Bank is 'not going to happen'
item.description: The US president has rejected calls from some members of the Israeli prime minister's coalition for Israel to fully annex the West Bank.

item.title: 'Unusual': Passenger on board Qantas flight speaks after emergency landing
item.description: The plane landed safely at Auckland Airport after concerns of a fire in the cargo hold. The local ambulance service said no passengers on board required its assistance.

item.title: Trump overcomes 'resistance' from China to transfer TikTok to US investors
item.description: The US president said Rupert Murdoch, along with other "world-class investors", would be involved in the deal.

item.title: PM in UK for military talks | Midday News Bulletin 26 September 2025
item.description: In this bulletin, hefty new tariffs on pharmaceuticals imported to the U-S, the Prime Minister arrives in the UK for security talks. And in sport, thousands expected for the annual A-F-L Grand Final parade in Melbourne's CBD.

item.title: Donald Trump announces 100% tariffs on branded medicines from October
Who is James Comey, the Trump critic and ex-FBI director who has just been indicted?
item.description: James Comey, who was fired by Donald Trump during the US president's first term, has been charged with two criminal counts.

item.title: Gaza death toll exceeds 65,500 as Israeli military intensifies strikes on enclave
item.description: The war in Gaza has now claimed more than 65,500 lives, according to Palestinian health officials, as Israeli forces intensify their campaign both inside the Strip and beyond. While Israel expands air and ground operations deep into Yemen, Palestinian Authority President Mahmoud Abbas is calling for a post-Hamas future and an immediate ceasefire.

item.title: The rise and fall of France's Nicolas Sarkozy after conviction
item.description: Former French president Nicolas Sarkozy has been sentenced to five years in prison after being found guilty of criminal conspiracy.

item.title: Butler criticises Trump's 'unfair' pharma tariffs that Ley says are 'shocking but unsurprising'
item.description: Medicines and pharmaceuticals are among Australia's top exports to the US, according to the Australian Bureau of Statistics.

item.title: SBS News in Easy English 25 September 2025
item.description: A daily five minute news wrap for English learners and people with disability.

item.title: UN says millions of young people are being left behind
item.description: Youth advocates from around the world have gathered at the UN headquarters in New York to participate in the high-level plenary meeting of the General Assembly. Their meeting marked the thirtieth anniversary of the World Programme of Action for Youth.

item.title: 'Exclusion or punishment': Fears of a growing problem in Australian schools
item.description: There's an anti-Palestinian racism "crisis" in Australian schools, according to a new report by an advocacy group, with students and teachers being punished for showing support for the Palestinian cause.

item.title: Black market tobacco boom a major threat | Evening News Bulletin 26 September 2025
item.description: In this bulletin, the boom of black-market tobacco becomes the nation's biggest health threat, strong words for Australia's Pacific Minister, as Vanuatu considers deals with Australia and China. And in sport, Australian hip hop star Baker Boy will perform with Snoop Dog at tomorrow's AFL grand final.

item.title: What time does the 2025 AFL grand final start? All the key details to know
item.description: Around 100,000 people are anticipated to go to the Geelong v Brisbane match this weekend.

item.title: Pharma stocks tumble following US pharma import tariffs
item.description: SBS Finance Editor Ricardo Gonçalves speaks with Shane Oliver from AMP and Marcus Bogdan from Blackmore Capital about the reaction to a US decision to apply 100% import tariffs to pharmaceutical products from Wednesday, plus all the latest from the sharemarket.

item.title: How a radical three-month experiment changed Australia's TV landscape forever
item.description: Celebrating five decades on air, a landmark SBS documentary shows how a radical idea evolved into a national platform for Indigenous and multicultural storytelling.

item.title: Court drops terror-related charge against member of Irish rap group Kneecap
item.description: The punk-rap group has issued a statement saying "they do not, and have never, supported Hamas or Hezbollah".

item.title: Anthony Albanese to meet King Charles, consult Middle East peace during UK visit
item.description: Anthony Albanese has swapped the US for the UK, landing in London for political talks and a conference of global leaders.

item.title: Morning News Bulletin 27 September 2025
item.description: Australia's health minister reacts to a fresh round of tariffs on pharmaceutical exports to the US; Fury over the digital alteration of an Australian film in China; And in sport, today is the day for this year's AFL Grand Final.

item.title: Dreaming of spreadsheets and battling stage fright: Behind the world Excel championships
item.description: From spreadsheets to showdowns, the Excel World Championship turns number-crunching into a high-stakes spectacle.

item.title: Australia has around 100,000 eggs in IVF storage. Some want to see unclaimed eggs donated
item.description: The demand for eggs far outpaces the number donated in Australia, leaving those wanting to start families with few options. Experts say something needs to change.

item.title: What's next for South Australia's algae bloom?
item.description: South Australia's algal bloom continues to spread, leading to significant environmental, ecological and mental health harm. Those impacts have been heard at a Senate inquiry examining support arrangements for those affected, but also long-term prevention strategies.

item.title: Dozens walk out on Netanyahu UN speech calling Palestinian recognition a 'mark of shame'
item.description: A procession of delegates exited the United Nations General Assembly hall ahead of Benjamin Netanyahu's speech denouncing Australia, France, Britain, Canada and other countries for recognising a Palestinian state.

item.title: New deep space antenna in Australia to aid exploration of universe while also creating local jobs
item.description: More than three years after it was first announced, a new deep space antenna is being brought online in Western Australia.

item.title: How to deep clean your fridge ahead of summer
item.description: Those neglected items at the back of your fridge can become a health hazard.

item.title: Six-pack diplomacy: Albanese joins Starmer and Carney for high-stakes talks
item.description: The Australian, British and Canadian leaders used a London summit to warn against the far-right and to discuss migration and renewed support for Palestinian statehood.

item.title: A mass delegate walk-out and what comes next: Benjamin Netanyahu's speech to the UN
item.description: Speaking at the United Nations, the Israeli leader pushed back in his harshest terms yet against a flurry of diplomatic moves that have deepened Israel's international isolation. But one thing was missing — any suggestion for what comes next, besides more war.

item.title: UN sanctions on Iran set to return after Russian, Chinese Security Council effort fails
item.description: All UN sanctions on Iran are set to be reinstated on the weekend after European powers accused Tehran of breaching a 2015 agreement aimed at preventing Iran from developing a nuclear weapon.

item.title: UN sanctions on Iran set to return after Russian, Chinese Security Council effort fails
item.description: All UN sanctions on Iran are set to be reinstated on the weekend after European powers accused Tehran of breaching a 2015 agreement aimed at preventing Iran from developing a nuclear weapon.

item.title: UN sanctions on Iran set to return after Russian, Chinese Security Council effort fails
item.description: All UN sanctions on Iran are set to be reinstated on the weekend after European powers accused Tehran of breaching a 2015 agreement aimed at preventing Iran from developing a nuclear weapon.

item.title: Trump isn't the first to push an unproven claim about autism. Why are they so pervasive?
item.description: One expert says an "information void" has allowed non-evidence-based claims and conspiracy theories around autism to flourish.

item.title: Midday News Bulletin 27 September 2025
item.description: Australia's PM declines to endorse Tony Blair for a key post-war Gaza role; Broadcasters to vote on excluding Israel from Eurovision; And in sport, Lewis Hamilton skips a testing session to sit at the bedside of his beloved dog.

item.title: Afraid of AI replacing you? Here are jobs that may be future-proof
item.description: Jobs including tax preparation, legal advice and education may have the lowest risk of being replaced by technology.

item.title: Evening News Bulletin 27 September 2025
item.description: Pacific Island leaders address the UN General Assembly on the climate crisis; Anthony Albanese discusses a Gaza reconstruction plan during a meeting with former British prime minister Tony Blair; and in sport, the Storm book a spot in the NRL grand final.

item.title: 'Is this still happening?': Elon Musk named in new Epstein files
item.description: Prince Andrew and PayPal co-founder Peter Thiel are among the other names in the documents released by Democrat politicians.

item.title: New Zealand won't recognise a Palestinian state 'at this time'
item.description: The decision puts the country at odds with its Commonwealth allies Australia, Canada and the United Kingdom.

item.title: INTERVIEW: Could a new UN declaration protect aid workers amid the growing death toll?
item.description: More than 100 states have signed an Australian-led declaration to protect aid workers. Australian Red Cross CEO Andrew Colvin explains what the declaration is aiming to achieve.

item.title: 'Unbroken whispers': How Indigenous women map whale songlines
item.description: A trio of First Nations researchers is blending traditional knowledge and science to map whale migration and advocate for improved conservation.

item.title: 'Jekyll and Hyde': How to win over Australia's most polarising bird
item.description: Culturally revered in Dreamtime stories but feared by cyclists, the magpie has a "Jekyll and Hyde" presence in our suburbs. But one expert says there are ways to win them over — even if you're magpie enemy number one.
